Global WorkflowGitHub Guidelines

AII GitHub Guidelines

Universal branching strategies, pull request workflows, and automated quality gates for all AII projects.

Chapter 1

Quick Reference Guide

Branching Rules

Mandatory prefix patterns for all feature work.

feature/*
bugfix/*

Pull Requests

Mandated for all protected branches.

Review Required
CI Passing

CI/CD Pipelines

Automated testing and deployment for every change.

Build
Test
Deploy

PR Quality

All PRs require 2 approvals and passing CI builds.

Strict
Automated

Review Time

Initial reviews expected within 24 business hours.

SLAs
Communication

Commit Style

Conventional Commits mandatory for all projects.

feat:
fix:
chore:

Your First Pull Request

Follow this workflow to submit your first contribution at AII:

1

Sync & Branch

Always start from the latest master branch and use the JIRA ID in your branch name.

bash
git checkout master && git pull
git checkout -b feature/JIRA-123-ui-fix
2

Commit Work

Follow Conventional Commits guidelines for your message.

bash
git add .
git commit -m "feat(ui): implement new glassmorphism theme"
3

Push & Open

Push and then click the GitHub link to open a PR against the master branch.

bash
git push -u origin feature/JIRA-123-ui-fix
Chapter 2

Development Workflow

Step-by-step flow from feature inception to production deployment.

STEP 01Feature Development

Create feature branches from development, implement changes, and open PRs.

STEP 02Preparing a Release

Create release branches from development for final stabilization.

STEP 03Testing in Staging

Deploy to testing environment. Fix discovered issues via additional PRs.

STEP 04Going Live

Merge release into master and development simultaneously.

STEP 05Production Deployment

Master triggers automatic production deployment via CI/CD pipelines.

Key Principle: All changes flow through PRs with mandatory reviews and CI checks, ensuring quality at every step regardless of stack.

Chapter 3

Branching Strategy

Branch Naming Convention

Standardized patterns for all AII repositories.

Regex Requirement
^ (master | development | refs/tags/.* | ((bugfix|hotfix|playground|defect|feature|release){1}/.+)) $
feature/login-page
bugfix/api-error
release/v1.2.0
hotfix/urgent-patch

Protected Branches

master
CRITICAL

Production branch. Contains only tested, production-ready code.

development
PROTECTED

Master integration branch. Base for all feature work.

release/*
LOCKED

Release candidates for staging testing and stabilization.

Crucial Restriction

NEVER commit directly to master, development, or any locked branches. All changes must be submitted via Pull Requests.

Chapter 4

Pull Request Process

Creation Checklist

Clear Title & Description

Explain the WHAT and WHY clearly.

Link Related Issues

Reference Jira tickets or internal issues.

Up-to-Date Branch

Merge latest changes from target first.

Focused Scope

One feature or bug fix per PR.

Merging Requirements

Code Owner Approval

Merging into any protected branch requires a review and approval from at least 1 designated code owner.

  • PRs should be small and focused.
  • Target for max 500 lines changed.
  • All discussions must be resolved.
Chapter 5

Code Review Standards

Quality & Standards

Reviewers verify adherence to the relevant technology guidelines and naming conventions.

Security Focus

Mandatory check for secret leakage, injection vulnerabilities, and authorization logic.

Automated Verification

CI/CD pipelines, unit tests, and linters must show green status.

Constructive Feedback

Focus on the code, not the person. Use suggestions feature for improvements.

Strict Rule: No Self-Merging

Do not merge your own PR unless explicitly allowed by the team lead. Collaborative review is the only way to maintain our quality bar.

Chapter 6

Commit Message Standards

Professional Examples

"Add user authentication validation"
"Fix login form bug #123"
"Update documentation for v2.1"

Use imperative mood and clear, concise subjects.

Messages to Avoid

"fixed stuff"
"changes"
"update"

Avoid vague, single-word messages that don't explain the intent.

Chapter 7

Testing & Quality Assurance

Comprehensive Coverage
All new features and bug fixes must include relevant unit or integration tests. Code without tests will not be approved.
Pre-Review Validation
Ensure all tests pass locally before requesting code review. Respect your reviewers' time by submitting a working codebase.
Chapter 8

Security & Documentation

Security First

"Never commit secrets, credentials, API keys, or other sensitive data to the repository."

Use environment variables, vault management, or secure configuration systems instead. Use .gitignore and git-secrets scans locally.

Documentation Sync

Keep documentation synchronized with code changes. Update README.md, technical docs, and internal wikis when implementing new capabilities.

Requirement: All public changes must have documentation updates.

Chapter 9

Conflict Resolution

Prevention is Better Than Cure

Always pull the latest changes from the target branch (e.g., master, development, or release/**) before starting work or creating a PR.

Before Starting

git checkout development
git pull origin development
git checkout -b feature/new-logic

Before PR

git checkout feature/new-logic
# Merge target branch
git merge development
# Resolve local conflicts
Chapter 10

CI/CD Status Requirements

Automated Tests

Unit & Integration checks must pass.

Code Quality

Linting and static analysis checks.

Build Status

Compilation and deployment staging checks.

All automated checks must pass before merging is permitted.

Chapter 11

Versioning Standards

Semantic Versioning 2.0.0

X . Y . Z

X
MAJOR

Breaking changes or incompatible API updates.

Y
MINOR

New functionality in a backwards compatible manner.

Z
PATCH

Backwards compatible bug fixes only.

Bug Fix

1.2.3 â†’ 1.2.4

New Feature

1.2.3 â†’ 1.3.0

Breaking Change

1.2.3 â†’ 2.0.0

Pre-release

2.0.0 â†’ 2.0.0-beta.1

Chapter 12

Changelog & Release Notes

Documenting Significance

Update the changelog or release notes in your PR if your changes are significant.

Questions or Support?

Following these guidelines ensures high-quality, maintainable code and smooth collaboration across the AII development team regardless of technology stack.
